content.definition: Endovascular placement of stents in the iliofemoral venous system to treat chronic venous outflow obstruction, most commonly due to May-Thurner syndrome (iliac vein compression) or post-thrombotic syndrome. Dedicated venous stents have improved outcomes compared to arterial stents used off-label.

non_thrombotic: May-Thurner syndrome with symptomatic iliofemoral compression
post_thrombotic: Post-thrombotic syndrome with chronic iliac obstruction
acute_thrombotic: Adjunct to pharmacomechanical thrombolysis for acute iliofemoral DVT
Underlying stenosis revealed after thrombus removal

access: Femoral vein (ipsilateral common femoral or popliteal)
imaging: IVUS superior to venography for stenosis detection

stent_selection.sizing: Generally 14-16 mm for common iliac, 12-14 mm for external iliac
stent_selection.landing_zones: Extend into healthy vein proximally and distally

chronic: Longer if underlying thrombophilia or prior DVT

content.statement: vascular:venous:iliac-stenting:definition is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Venous that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding vascular:venous:iliac-stenting:definition helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of vascular:venous:iliac-stenting:definition include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of vascular:venous:iliac-stenting:definition.

learning_objectives: Know indications for iliofemoral venous stenting
Understand difference between thrombotic and non-thrombotic indications
clinical_pearls: IVUS is SUPERIOR to venography for detecting iliac stenosis
Dedicated venous stents outperform repurposed arterial stents
Non-thrombotic (May-Thurner) has better patency than post-thrombotic
Size generously: 14-16 mm for common iliac

citations.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
